data.name: Submersible
data.credits: UE5:Underwater Blueprint V2, other assets from Quixel MegaScans

description.text: The visuals involve a character falling from the sky and landing underwater. While underwater, the character is surrounded by oceanic rocks and flora. An infinite expansive ocean is an image I keep coming back to, as it helps me convey feelings of isolation, absence, and disorientation. This feeling/vision of being underwater further adds another dimension of distance, with a whole alien world and no words to communicate with. Using the fast blurred motion and low angle of the camera I aimed to add to the disorientation.

Knowing I wanted to create an underwater scene, I started looking for ways to do it. I came across a blueprint (linked in credits) that generates beautiful oceans effortlessly. Using this as a stepping point, I started creating massive monolithic stone landscapes using Quixel Bridge and then added vibrant flora to add to the alienness of the scene. Hardware issues kept bogging me down and I wasn’t able to do everything I had set out to do. I was aiming to add oceanic alien fauna as well and then some more ethereal lighting and underwater fog. Given more time, I would aim to create ephemeral ruins in the ocean too.

data.name: MisMatch
data.credits: Dog Model, Piglet Model, Bear Model, Ice Material

description.text: This project explores the absurdities present in the nomenclature of various proper nouns in our colloquial languages. Through this scene, I conceived three fictional creatures by playing at their root nouns and placed them in a jungle setting. The creatures are Sea Dog ( German word for seal: Seehund), Earth Pig (aardvark: Erdferkel), and Ice Bear (Polar Bear: Eisbär). They are created by replacing the materials of these animal models with the materials of these elements.

The hardest part of this assignment for me was the composition and compositing of the scene. Getting the lighting right for a jungle scene and making the jungle scene look right was a tricky challenge. I played around with the landscape tool, auto landscape material, foliage tool, and tree packs but still, the scene looked too unnatural to me. I think playing with the exponential fog and post-process volume and giving it a warmer tone helped bring it closer to the vision in my head. I’d still like to learn how to get better at environmental lighting and create more natural-looking scenes.
